raw_text:
Blair backs 'pre-election budget'
 
 Tony Blair has backed Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report amid opposition claims he was too bullish about the state of the UK economy.
 
 In a speech in Edinburgh, the prime minister said Thursday's report reinforced stability and opportunity. And that would be central to Labour's next election campaign, planning for which was already well advanced. Mr Brown earlier denied his economic forecasts were too optimistic - but refused to rule out future tax rises.
 
 He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "No politician should make the mistake that John Major and his colleagues made in 1992 of saying no matter what the circumstances are, they can make all sorts of guarantees on every individual thing.
 
 "That is not what politicians should do, it would not be responsible to do." Mr Brown insisted his spending plans were "affordable" and he could afford to be optimistic because Britain was now a stable, low-inflation economy and house prices were now stabilising. Mr Blair praised his chancellor for his role in creating economic stability, which he said was the "cornerstone" of Labour's programme.
 
 In a speech at Edinburgh's Napier University, he said Labour would publish over the next few months "a rich agenda for future policy in any possible third term".
 
 "In every area of work there is a detailed plan for the future, much clearer than those in 1997 or 2001. All of it fits together around common themes of opportunity, security and stability for all," Mr Blair said. In his pre-Budget report, Mr Brown surprised some City experts by forecasting UK growth at between 3% and 3.5% for next year. Many believe the figure is more likely to be under 3% - and fear tax rises or spending cuts, saying tax receipts have been overestimated. Carl Emmerson, from the Institute for Fiscal Studies, told BBC News: "He thinks everything will come out in the wash and it will, in fact, be OK. We're not so sure." David Page, of Investec Securities, said: "His forecast that he will meet the golden rule with a margin of £8bn is way too optimistic. "It's going to take a significant turnaround in the economy to meet these targets."
 
 Conservative Shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin said: "I can't find a single economic forecaster from the IMF to the Institute of Fiscal Studies who believes anything other than the chancellor has got a black hole in his finances. "In order to deal with that he will have to raise taxes after the next general election." Mr Letwin accused the chancellor of using "fancy statistics" to hide public service failures. Vincent Cable, for the Liberal Democrats, called on Mr Brown to open up the government's books to the National Audit Office, to see if he had met his "golden rule". "It is very clear that there are some serious loose ends in government public spending," Mr Cable told MPs.
llama3.2:1b: Tony Blair has backed Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report amid opposition claims of optimism being too high.
Brown denied making guarantees, saying politicians should focus on responsibility rather than making promises.
He predicted a stable economy with low inflation and house prices stabilizing.
Blair said Labour would publish an agenda for future policy in the next few months, citing detailed plans for areas such as opportunity, security, and stability.
Critics questioned the forecast, including Carl Emmerson of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, who believes tax rises or spending cuts may be needed to meet targets.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair backed Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report, saying it reinforced stability and opportunity for Labour's next election campaign.
However, many experts believe the forecasted 3% UK growth and £8bn margin of error are too optimistic, with potential tax rises or spending cuts.

Conservative Shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin said there was a "black hole" in Mr Brown's finances, while Liberal Democrat Vincent Cable called for greater transparency over government public spending.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair supports Gordon Brown's pre-budget report and believes it will help Labour's next election campaign.

Critics of the report, including Conservative Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin, believe it overestimates economic growth and the government's ability to meet its financial targets without raising taxes.
They question the accuracy of the forecast and express doubt about Mr. Brown's ability to handle public spending effectively.

Blair also says his spending plans are "affordable" and that Britain is now a stable, low-inflation economy with house prices stabilising.

Brown surprises City experts by forecasting strong growth, but faces skepticism about tax increases.
Conservative Letwin criticizes Brown for using fancy statistics to hide public service failures, while Liberal Democrat Cable calls for government openness regarding spending.
qwen2.5:3b: Tony Blair supported Chancellor Gordon Brown’s pre-Budget report, emphasizing its stability and opportunity for Labour's next election campaign.
While criticized as overly optimistic about the UK economy by opposition groups, Brown maintained his stance, highlighting economic stability and a stabilizing housing market.
In his Edinburgh speech, Blair praised Brown’s contribution to creating economic stability as crucial to Labour’s program.

However, critics like Oliver Letwin from the Conservative Party and Vincent Cable of the Liberal Democrats questioned Brown's fiscal forecasts and called for greater transparency in government finances.

Mr Brown later denied his economic forecasts were too optimistic but refused to rule out future tax rises.

He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "No politician should make the mistake that John Major and his colleagues made in 1992 of saying no matter what the circumstances are, they can make all sorts of guarantees on every individual thing.
That is not what politicians should do, it would not be responsible to do."
Mr Brown insisted his spending plans were affordable and he could afford to be optimistic because Britain was now a stable, low-inflation economy and house prices were now stabilising.
Mr Blair praised his chancellor for his role in creating economic stability which he said is the cornerstone of Labour's programme.
In a speech at Edinburgh's Napier University, Labour would publish over the next few months "a rich agenda for future policy in any possible third term".
"In every area of work there is a detailed plan for the future, much clearer than those in 1997 or 2001.
All of it fits together around common themes of opportunity, security and stability for all," Mr Blair said.
smollm:1.7b: Identifying the main ideas and key concepts of the text.

Using plain language to convey the same message as the original text.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Blair has backed Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report but called his financial outlook uncertain due to potential issues like tax cuts or spending reductions.
He emphasized that in the future, Labour would publish a detailed policy agenda.
Mr. Brown was cautious about his growth projections (3-3.5%) fearing possible tax rises and spending changes, while others questioned his financial stability with experts.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Prime Minister, Tony Blair, has praised Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-election budget, claiming that the state of the UK economy is stable and opportunity is ripe for Labour's next campaign.
Speaking at Edinburgh University, Mr Blair insisted that the government's fiscal policies were "affordable" and said Britain was now a low-inflation economy, with house prices stabilising.
The Prime Minister defended his economic forecasts, which he claimed were "reinforced stability and opportunity", as Labour publishes its plans for future policy in any future term.
However, some experts believe that the government's forecast for next year may not be met by economic growth of between 3% and 3.5%, leaving tax receipts overestimated.

Liberal Democrats have called on Mr Brown to open up government books to see if he had met his "golden rule", which would mean meeting public service failures, while Conservative economist Oliver Letwin suggested a significant turnaround in the economy was needed before any further tax rises could be considered.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary provided is concise and captures the main ideas of a text discussing Tony Blair's position on the pre-election budget report and his stance on Labour's next election campaign strategy, as well as reactions to this by various parties.
It also provides information about the current state of the UK economy, with predictions that Britain will have stability and opportunities for growth under Gordon Brown's leadership.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Blair endorsed Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report, emphasizing its role as a foundation for Labour's election strategy.
In his Edinburgh speech, Blair highlighted the report's focus on stability and opportunity, which would form the core of their campaign plans.

Despite opposition claims that Brown's economic forecasts were overly optimistic (projecting UK growth between 3% and 3.5%, potentially underestimating tax receipts), Mr. Blair defended his chancellor, praising Brown's efforts in creating a stable, low-inflation economy with stabilizing house prices.
Brown insisted his spending plans were "affordable," citing Britain's improved financial status as the basis for optimism.
However, several experts expressed doubts about these projections, warning of potential tax rises or spending cuts if Brown fails to meet economic targets.

Opposition figures, including Conservative Shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin and Liberal Democrat Vincent Cable, criticized the chancellor for employing "fancy statistics" to obscure public service shortcomings and called for greater government financial transparency.
